titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Gustaf E. Lindskog Papers
titlestmt.author: Finding aid by Toby A. Appel

publicationstmt.publisher: Medical Historical Library, Harvey Cushing / John Hay Whitney Medical Library

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Tuesday April 30, 2019 at 02:00

did.unittitle: Gustaf E. Lindskog Papers

repository.corpname: Medical Historical Library, Harvey Cushing / John Hay Whitney Medical Library

did.abstract: Thoracic surgeon Gustaf Lindskog was a member of the Department of Surgery from 1933 until his retirement in 1971. He chaired the department from 1948 to 1966. The collection consists primarily of his reports as head of the Thoracic Surgery Service of New Haven Hospital, talks including history of surgery lectures given at Yale, medical illustrations, and reprints. The restricted boxes contain Lindskog's notes on his surgical operations on named patients.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Gift of Carl Lindskog, 2011. Additional materials belonging to Lindskog, especially his history of surgery lectures, were donated earlier and added to the collection in 2015.

custodhist.head: Custodial History
custodhist.p: These materials were owned by Gustaf E. Lindskog.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Part of this collection is open for research.
Descriptions of operations and correspondence with or about named patients are restricted.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Reports in Lindskog's official capacity as professor of surgery and surgeon are the property of Yale University. Yale does not own copyright to other materials.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Gustaf E. Lindskog Papers, Historical Library, Cushing/Whitney Medical Library, Yale University, New Haven, CT

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Gustaf E. Lindskog, thoracic surgeon at Yale, was born in Boston in 1903. He graduated from the Massachusettts Agricultural College (now University of Massachusetts) in 1923, and received his M.D. from Harvard Medical School in 1928. He interned at Lakeside Hospital in Cleveland. From 1929 to 1932, he was a resident in surgery at Yale. The following year he was a National Research Council Fellow at Massachusetts General Hospital in Boston. In 1933, he returned to Yale as instructor of surgery and rose through the ranks to become the William Carmalt Professor of Surgery in 1948. Lindskog chaired the department from 1948 to 1966. In 1971 he retired but remained active in the Yale community. During World War II, he served for four years as a commander in the Navy Medical Corps and was stationed part of the time at the Philadelphia Naval Yard. In 1943, he worked with Louis S. Goodman and Alfred Gilman on the development of chemotherapy at Yale. They used nitrogen mustard in the treatment of a patient with lymphosarcoma. Lindskog was widely recognized for his contributions to thoracic surgery. He pioneered in the surgical resection of chronic pulmonary abscess. In addition to his many research articles, he was co-author with Averill Liebow and William Glenn on three editions of a major textbook of thoracic surgery, Thoracic and Cardiovascular Surgery with Related Pathology (1953, 1962, 1975). He died at the age of 99 in 2002.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The collection contains reports of the Thoracic Service at Yale, 1938-1946; statistics of various other surgical operations at Yale; lists of surgical residents; typescripts of lectures before various groups; medical illustrations by Armin Hemberger and others, and photographic illustrations from some of his papers; manuscripts of possibly unpublished papers; other miscellany; and reprints of Lindskog's articles. The restricted boxes contain Lindskog's descriptions of his surgical operations on named patients.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized in seven series: 1. Yale University School of Medicine Department of Surgery. 2. Lectures before various groups. 3. Medical drawings and photographs for some of Lindskog's publications. 4. Miscellany. 5. Reprints of Lindskog's papers. 6. Notes on surgical operations (restricted). 7. Lindskog's history of surgery lectures at Yale.

scopecontent.p: Note: Series 6 (restricted) is related to Series 1.

did.unittitle: Annotated reprints by others

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Six reprints by Alfred Blalock, George S. Stevenson, Willard B. Soper, Sherwin B. Nuland, Edward A. Boyden, and William W. L. Glenn. William W. L. Glenn, "Some Reflections on the coronary bypass operation," Circulation, 14 (1972): 869-877, contains a letter from Glenn to Lindskog.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: This series is restricted because the material contains patient names. Titles have been transcribed from Dr. Lindskog's original folders

did.unittitle: Selected Operative Notes, Lakeside Hospital, Cleveland

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Description of the operation procedure dictated by Lindskog, and retrospectively annotated by Dr. Lindskog in 1995. One sheet per case.

did.unittitle: Selective Operative Notes, Orthopedic Surgery

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: These and the succeeding notes taken at Yale are onionskin copies of typed reports which include the name of the patient, the date, the room where the operation took place, the names of the operator and assistant operator(s), the diagnosis, the name of the operation, the type of anesthesia, a lengthy description of the surgical procedure, and a prognosis.

did.unittitle: Selected Operative Notes & Reports, Alphabetic, A to E

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series of notes, alphabetic by patient name, describes operations from 1960 to 1971. Notes are on carbon copies of forms from Grace-New Haven Community Hospital and Yale-New Haven Hospital. There are some interleaved copies of correspondence, usually to referring physicians, that date back to at least 1948.

did.unittitle: Folders on individual patients

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: These 23 folders, arranged alphabetically by name of patient, contain correspondence with patients, family, and other other physicians. Many cases are referrals and include a letter from the referring physician.

did.unittitle: Lindskog's History of Surgery Annual Lectures

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: These are texts of Gustaf Lindskog's annual or nearly-annual History of Surgery lectures. The Department of Surgery, sometimes joined by the Department of History of Science and Medicine, for many years sponsored a series of five history of surgery lectures held weekly in February and March. Usually they took place in the Beaumont Room or the Historical Library. The last in the series was the invited Samuel Clark Harvey Lecture named after a previous chairman of the Department of Surgery who retired in 1948. Most of these folders were found later and added to the Lindskog Papers as another series. Titles were transcribed from previous folders kept by Lindskog. Several of the lectures were published. See Lindskog's reprints in Box 2. See also other Lindskog presentations in Box 1.

did.unittitle: "The History of Pulmonary Resection," Samuel Clark Harvey Lecture
"Diagnostic Procedures," History of Surgery Course
"Boerhaave at Leyden: The Renaissance of Clinical Teaching," presented in the Historical Library

"American Physician-Botanists of the 19th Century"
"The Life and Times of Guillaume Dupuytren," History of Surgery Lecture

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Folder contains a later version of the lecture intended for publication, titled "Guillaume Dupytren: A Bicentennial Memoire," and correspondence with Arthur Baue, Chairman, Department of Surgery, and Martin C. Carey, Harvard Medical School, 1977.

did.unittitle: "Ferdinand Sauerbruch and His Contributions to Thoracic Surgery," History of Surgery Lecture
"Remembrances of Former Things--Foreign Bodies," History of Surgery Lecture

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes a program listing a series of five lectures sponsored by by the Department of Surgery and the Department of the History of Science and Medicine. Lindskog's was the first lecture to be presented on Janaury 31, 1972. On successive weeks, lectures were to be presented by Urich H. Weill, M.D., Sherwin B. Nuland, M.D., H.C. Stansel, Jr., M.D., and finally the Samuel Clark Harvey Lecture to be given by George Rosen, M.D.

did.unittitle: "The Story of Tracheoesophageal Fistula," History of Surgery Lecture

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This lecture is in part autobiographical.

did.unittitle: "Oliver Wendell Holmes," History of Surgery Lecture

did.unittitle: "Recollections of a Surgical Training," History of Surgery Lecture

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Plus list of History of Surgery lectures, 1980. In this autobiographical lecture, Lindskog recalls incidents from his training at Harvard Medical School, including his interaction with Harvey Cushing, and from his internship at Lakeside Hospital in Cleveland.

did.unittitle: "P.-C.-A. Louis (1787-1872) and the Rise of Medical Science in France," History of Surgery Lecture
